content:
As part of my PhD, I implemented using Vector a type for finite permutations on n elements - it is isomorphic to Equiv.Perm (Fin n), but is faster in practice when composing and accessing elements.

Now that my dissertation is written, I'm beginning the slow task of moving all the things I have written into Mathlib where appropriate. #24960 begins that effort.

My hope is that I've chosen a suitable amount to cover at once here - the type definition and then the natural group and scalar multiplication instances.

The end goal in a sense, incidentally, is working with the following type:

structure FinitePerm where
  len : â„•
  toPermOf : PermOf len
  toPermOf_minLen : toPermOf.minLen = len
  deriving DecidableEq

Which is essentially the sigma type of all the PermOf n quotiented by, essentially, permutations being equivalent, though this isn't actually how we construct it because it was easier to do things computably that way. What's quite nice about this is that it gives a straightforward and computable way to work with finite permutations as you might with pencil and paper mathematics.

I'd like to link it to permsOfFinset though I haven't done that yet.
